column10: Spring 2009 European Council in relation to the Lisbon Strategy
column12:
European Parliament resolution on the input to the Spring 2009 European Council in relation to the Lisbon Strategy

B6-0109/2009

The European Parliament,

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'Implementation report for the Community Lisbon Programme 2008-2010'(1) and country-specific recommendations,

– having regard to the 27 National Lisbon Reform Programmes, as presented by the Member States,

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'The European Interest: Succeeding in the age of globalisation'(2),

– having regard to the Commission communication on progress in implementing the single market review,

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'Reporting on market access and setting the framework for more effective international regulatory cooperation'(3),

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'An updated strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training'(4),

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'New Skills for New Jobs – Anticipating and matching labour market and skills needs'(5),

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'Cohesion policy: investing in the real economy'(6),

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'A European economic recovery plan'(7),

– having regard to the Commission proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1927/2006 on establishing the Globalisation Adjustment Fund(8),

– having regard to the European Council's conclusions of March 2000, March 2001, March 2005, October 2005, March 2006, March 2007 and March 2008,

– having regard to its resolution of 15 November 2007 on the European Interest: succeeding in the age of globalisation(9),

– having regard to its resolution of 20 February 2008 on the Integrated Guidelines for Growth and Jobs (Part: broad guidelines for the economic policies of the PlaceNameplaceMemberPlaceType States and the Community): Launching the new cycle (2008-2010)(10),

– having regard to its resolution of 18 November 2008 on the EMU@10: The first ten years of Economic and Monetary Union and future challenges(11),

– having regard to Rule 103(2) of its Rules of Procedure,

COMMENCEMENT OF THE FOURTH SESSION

The Fourth Session of the Ninth Parliament was opened by His Excellency the President the Hon. Mwai Kibaki, EGH, MP on Wednesday March 16 2005.

By the close of business on Thursday November 3, 2005 the House had a total of 98 Sittings.

LEGISLATIVE PROPOSALS

A total of 25 Bills were brought before the House. Five of the Bills, the Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) Bill, the Sugar (Amendment) Bill, the National Cereals and Produce Board (Amendment) Bill, the Sexual Offences Bill and the Cotton (Amendment) Bill, are Private Members’ Bills by Mr. Charles Keter (KANU), Prof. Ruth Oniang’o (KANU), Mr. William Samoei Ruto (KANU), Ms. Njoki Ndung’u (NARC) and Dr. Julia Ojiambo (NARC) respectively. The rest of the Bills were Government sponsored.

The Sugar (Amendment) Bill was subsequently surrendered by the sponsor to the Minister for Agriculture during its Second Reading stage while the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill was withdrawn by the Attorney General. The rest of the private members’ bills lapsed before the Second Reading stage.

During the Session, His Excellency the President refused to assent to the Banking (Amendment) Bill, the Wildlife (Conservation and Management) (Amendment) Bill and the National Social Health Insurance Fund Bill passed in 2004 via Memoranda communicated to the House. The House debated the Memorandum on the Banking (Amendment) Bill and resolved to refer the Bill to the Minister for Finance for further consultations with stakeholders. The other two Memoranda had not been deliberated upon by the House at the time of prorogation in November, 2005.

Three Bills, namely, the Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) Bill, the HIV and AIDS Prevention Bill and the Statistics Bill, 2005 remained on the Order of Business but never came for First Reading.

Seven Acts were passed by Parliament last year. These include the Public Procurement Act, the Supplementary Appropriations Act, the Appropriations Act, the Finance Act, the Forests Act, the Privatization Act, and the Kenya Railways Act, 2005.

The Bills are listed below;
  1. The Public Procurement and Disposal Bill, 2005
  2. The Sugar (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  3. The National Cereals and Produce Board (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  4. The Witness Protection Bill, 2005
  5. The International Crimes Bill, 2005
  6. The National Museums and Heritage (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  7. The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, 2005
  8. The Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) (No. 1) Bill, 2005
  9. The Cotton (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  10. The National Social Security Pensions Trust Bill, 2005
  11. Presidential Memorandum on The National Social Health Insurance Fund Bill, 2004
  12. Presidential Memorandum on The Banking (Amendment) Bill, 2004  
  13. Presidential Memorandum on The Wildlife (Conservation and Management) (Amendment) Bill, 2004
  14. The Supplementary Appropriations Bill, 2005
  15. The Kenya Maritime Authority Bill, 2005
  16. The Finance Bill, 2005
  17. The Retirement Benefits (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  18. Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 2), 2005
  19. The Forests Bill, 2005
  20. The Privatization Bill, 2005
  21. The HIV and AIDS Prevention and Control Bill, 2005
  22. The Kenya Railways Corporation (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  23. The Appropriation Bill, 2005
  24. The Statistics Bill, 2005
  25. The Sexual Offences Bill, 2005

MOTIONS

A total of 82 Notices of Motions were given, 79 of them debated, 63 adopted and 2 negatived.

QUESTIONS
Out of a total of 887 questions filed by Members, 712 were ordinary and 175 by Private Notice. 681 ordinary questions were asked, 401 were answered, and 225 deferred and 56 dropped. Of the 246 Questions by Private Notice asked, 146 of them were answered, 78 deferred and 24 dropped.

MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
Ministers issued a total of 49 Ministerial Statements.
      
PAPERS LAID
A total of 169 papers were laid before the House. Seven were Sessional Papers presented by Ministers.

CONFERENCES

INTERNATIONAL AND REGIONAL CONFERENCES  COMMONWEALTH PARLIAMENTARY ASSOCIATION (CPA)

The CPA Plenary Conference was held in Fiji in September, 2005
The CPA Regional Conference was held in Cameroon in August 2005
The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Kenya Branch was represented at the above conferences.
The Branch successfully hosted the 18th Commonwealth Speakers’ and Presiding Officers’ conference with close to 120 delegates from over 40 countries in attendance.  The Conference took place between 3rd to 8th January, 2006 at the Safari Park Hotel.

INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION (IPU)
113th IPU Plenary Conference in April 2005 in Manila, Philippines
IPU Conference in September/October 2005 in Geneva, Switzerland
114th IPU Conference in May 2006 in Nairobi.

PAN-AFRICAN PARLIAMENT
3rd session of the Pan-African Parliament was held from March 29th to April 11th 2005 in Midrand, South Africa.
4th session of the Pan-African Parliament was held in Midrand, South Africa in September 2005

AFRICAN, CARRIBEAN AND PACIFIC /EUROPEAN UNION (ACP/EU)
The 9th  Session of the ACP/EU joint Parliamentary Assembly held in Bamako, Mali from 13th  March to 2nd April 2005
Committee on Economic Development, Finance and Trade of the ACP/EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly was held in Brussels, Belgium in September 2005
10th Session of the ACP/EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to be held in Edinburgh, UK in November 2005

CHALLENGES
Despite the smooth movement of business in the House so far, there are a few challenges that remain to be surmounted.

1.Professional Staff Training:
The Department is in dire need of professional training to allow both old and new staff to acquire new skills and knowledge in Parliamentary Studies.  

2.Workspace:
While the National Assembly in general is struggling with the problem of accommodating members, officials and staff, the department strongly feels that lack of reasonable space has tended to slow down business in the House. 


RECOMMENDATIONS

It is therefore recommended that staff be provided with the requisite professional training and exposure so as to enhance competence and efficiency. It is also recommended that more space be allocated to the unit as a matter of urgency.

  3. The National Cereals and Produce Board (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  4. The Witness Protection Bill, 2005
  5. The International Crimes Bill, 2005
  6. The National Museums and Heritage (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  7. The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, 2005
  8. The Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) (No. 1) Bill, 2005
  9. The Cotton (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  10. The National Social Security Pensions Trust Bill, 2005
  11. Presidential Memorandum on The National Social Health Insurance Fund Bill, 2004
  12. Presidential Memorandum on The Banking (Amendment) Bill, 2004  
  13. Presidential Memorandum on The Wildlife (Conservation and Management) (Amendment) Bill, 2004
  14. The Supplementary Appropriations Bill, 2005
  15. The Kenya Maritime Authority Bill, 2005
  16. The Finance Bill, 2005
  17. The Retirement Benefits (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  18. Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 2), 2005
  19. The Forests Bill, 2005

  22. The Kenya Railways Corporation (Amendment) Bill, 2005
  23. The Appropriation Bill, 2005
  24. The Statistics Bill, 2005
  25. The Sexual Offences Bill, 2005

– having regard to the Commission communication entitled 'Implementation report for the Community Lisbon Programme 2008-2010'(1) and country-specific recommendations,
